text:
# ENERGY TRANSITION

The energy sector in Europe is responsible for over <font size="6">70%</font> of total greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. A transition to renewable energy production is a key element of the decarbonisation of economy.
title: FWB1

text: The contribution of the energy sector to emissions has been quite stable in the last 15 years, with a visible little deflection in 2019 associated to the Covid-19 lockdowns.
title: StickyRight1L

text:
While the share of renewables in the overall energy mix has been steadily growing in the last 15 years - reaching 22% of gross energy consumption in 2020 - EU countries have set challenging targets towards the 2050 carbon neutrality and the 2030 interim 55% global GHG reduction goals.

<--EXPAND-SMALL-->

In order to achieve those targets, each country has put in place National Energy and Climate Plans that define specific strategies and targets for each domain of intervention.
title: FWB2

text:
In particular, the European Commission’s current goal for renewable energies is to achieve at least a 32% share in the energy mix across Europe by 2030.

<--EXPAND-SMALL-->

The Renewable Energy directive sets the common target for the amount of renewable energy in the EU’s energy consumption.
The proposed revision suggests further evolution of the 32% target to accelerate the take-up of renewables in the EU.
title: StickyRight2L

text: The transition away from fossil energy sources is a daunting task for economies that have developed based on fossil energy sources, and the growth of renewable energy sources production should be carefully planned to make sure that planning of their deployment is optimised. Information derived from Earth Observation can be a precious support tool to streamline activities in the renewable energy sector: from planning and development - energy potential hindcasting, siting, EIA, plant design, electrification - to operations and maintenance - energy yield nowcasting and forecasting, operations planning and monitoring. <--EXPAND-->
title: FWB4

text:
## Planning and development

EO satellites track relevant parameters for on-shore renewables,  such as wind patterns, cloud cover and solar irradiance (as in this
animation). They track the metocean suite of variables (wind, wave and climate) for off-shore wind farms. And storage potential in hydro reservoirs can be monitored as well.
title: StickyRight3L

text:
## Operations and maintenance

EO satellites can support management and mitigation of environmental issues associated with large infrastructure investment projects, e.g. measuring environmental changes due to encroachment of human activity around hydropower reservoirs.

They can also play an important role in monitoring and maintaining the infrastructure, e.g. by checking hydropower dam
stability using PS-InSAR, or monitoring leakage along pipelines when it comes to other, existing energy infrastructure.

The image on the right shows, for instance, the [Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline leak](https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Satellites_detect_methane_plume_in_Nord_Stream_leak) which occurred during the first week of October 2022.
title: StickyRight4L

text:
## The Austrian energy scenario While Austria is a virtuous country when it comes to renewable energy, with a share well above EU average for the last 20 years (or more), it has set ambitious goals towards 2030 within its National Energy and Climate Plan, with a planned share of renewables between 45% and 50% of gross final energy consumption (with a striking ambition of 100% of electricity produced from renewables).
The current Austrian scenario sees a predominant role of hydropower, overriding by three times the total of all other renewable sources (EUROSTAT statistics). Wind is the second source by importance, surpassing solid biofuels since 2004. Nonetheless, current wind energy production is restricted to a very limited geographic area.


How can GTIF play a role in this energy scenario?

GTIF provides various EXPLORE TOOLS for you to investigate the challenges and opportunities in the energy transition.
